# Association of caffeine with renal and other short-term outcomes in neonates with hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy undergoing therapeutic hypothermia.**DOI:** 10.1136/bmjpo-2025-003720

**Authors:** RakeshLavu, NicholasNicoletti, SarahWorley, SubhashPuthuraya, HanyAly, CeydaAcun

**Journal:** BMJ paediatrics open

**DOI:** 10.1136/bmjpo-2025-003720

## Abstract

To evaluate the association of caffeine with renal and other short-term clinical outcomes in neonates with moderate or severe hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (HIE) undergoing therapeutic hypothermia (TH).
This retrospective cohort study included neonates born at ≥36 weeks gestational age with moderate or severe HIE treated with TH at our centre between January 2013 and December 2022. In 2019, there was a practice change to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine citrate dose for moderate/severe HIE, forming two cohorts (non-caffeine vs caffeine). The primary outcome was acute kidney injury (AKI), defined by modified Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes criteria. Secondary outcomes included daily serum creatinine, blood-urea nitrogen (BUN), urine output, HIE-pattern lesion on brain-MRI, early EEG background grade, seizures, duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay, tube-feeding at discharge and in-hospital mortality.
85 neonates met the inclusion criteria; 38 received caffeine, and 47 did not. AKI incidence was lower in the caffeine group (29% vs 47%), although not statistically significant (p=0.09). BUN levels and serum creatinine levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 3-5 (p<0.05). MRI abnormalities consistent with HIE were more frequent in the caffeine group (60% vs 36%, p=0.028), particularly in infants with moderate HIE (p=0.004). EEG background profiles differed, with caffeine-exposed neonates displaying fewer severe (34% vs 65%) and more mild-to-moderate patterns. No significant differences were noted in other secondary outcomes.
Caffeine during TH lowered serum creatinine and BUN but did not significantly reduce AKI and was associated with higher rates of MRI lesions. Prospective, dose-controlled trials with pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up are needed to clarify caffeine's renal benefits and neurological safety in neonatal HIE.

objective to evaluate the association of caffeine with renal and other short-term clinical outcomes in neonates with moderate or severe hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) undergoing therapeutic hypothermia (th). study design this retrospective cohort study included neonates born at ≥36 weeks gestational age with moderate or severe hie treated with th at our centre between january 2013 and december 2022. in 2019, there was a practice change to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine citrate dose for moderate/severe hie, forming two cohorts (non-caffeine vs caffeine). the primary outcome was acute kidney injury (aki), defined by modified kidney disease: improving global outcomes criteria. secondary outcomes included daily serum creatinine, blood-urea nitrogen (bun), urine output, hie-pattern lesion on brain-mri, early eeg background grade, seizures, duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay, tube-feeding at discharge and in-hospital mortality. results 85 neonates met the inclusion criteria; 38 received caffeine, and 47 did not. aki incidence was lower in the caffeine group (29% vs 47%), although not statistically significant (p=0.09). bun levels and serum creatinine levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 3–5 (p<0.05). mri abnormalities consistent with hie were more frequent in the caffeine group (60% vs 36%, p=0.028), particularly in infants with moderate hie (p=0.004). eeg background profiles differed, with caffeine-exposed neonates displaying fewer severe (34% vs 65%) and more mild-to-moderate patterns. no significant differences were noted in other secondary outcomes. conclusion caffeine during th lowered serum creatinine and bun but did not significantly reduce aki and was associated with higher rates of mri lesions. prospective, dose-controlled trials with pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up are needed to clarify caffeine’s renal benefits and neurological safety in neonatal hie. back to top what is already known on this topic caffeine is widely used in preterm infants and observationally linked to less acute kidney injury (aki), but its renal and neurological effects during therapeutic hypothermia (th) for term hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) are unknown. what this study adds in term neonates who underwent th, a single dose of intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine citrate given within the first 24 hours lowered serum creatinine and blood-urea nitrogen without reducing aki and was unexpectedly associated with more brain mri lesions and a redistribution of early eeg backgrounds (fewer severe, more mild/moderate grades). how this study might affect research, practice or policy the findings caution against routine caffeine use for nephro-protection in terms of hie and underscore the need for prospective dose-controlled trials that include neuro-imaging safety endpoints. introduction hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) affects approximately 1–4 per 1000 live births in high-resource settings and remains a major cause of neonatal death and lifelong neurodisability. 1 therapeutic hypothermia (th) initiated within 6 hours of birth improves survival and neurodevelopmental outcomes, yet does not prevent multisystem sequelae. 2 acute kidney injury (aki) occurs in 20%–40% of infants with hie who underwent th and is independently associated with higher mortality, longer intensive-care stay and poorer cognitive scores at school age. 3–5 furthermore, neonates with hie who develop aki are at an increased risk of chronic kidney disease in later childhood and adolescence. 6 a single-centre cohort study demonstrated that neonatal aki in hie is associated with abnormal brain mri findings and lower bayley developmental scores. 7 8 despite the clear implication of aki on mortality and morbidity, there are currently limited therapeutic interventions available. several studies have investigated the potential of methylxanthines, including aminophylline and theophylline, to improve renal outcomes in neonates. 9–12 both drugs have demonstrated benefits in enhancing urine output (uop) and reducing the incidence of aki, likely through their renal vasodilatory and diuretic effects. 13 however, due to limited data on side effect profiles and pharmacokinetics of aminophylline and theophylline in neonates, they are infrequently used in clinical practice. a recent multicentre cohort of 4675 infants showed that methylxanthine exposure in neonates with hie who underwent th did not increase mortality or major morbidities, renewing interest in this drug class. 12 caffeine, another methylxanthine, is well tolerated in preterm infants and is widely used in neonatal intensive care units (nicus) for apnoea of prematurity. 14 15 experimental data show that adenosine-a1 receptor antagonism enhances glomerular filtration and natriuresis, while anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects may mitigate ischaemia–reperfusion injury. 16 observational studies in very-low-birth-weight cohorts link early caffeine exposure to a lower aki risk, 17 18 and a phase-i pharmacokinetic study in term neonates demonstrated predictable distribution during th. 19 because caffeine crosses the blood brain barrier and may raise cerebral metabolic demand, its net neurological impact in already-injured term brains remains uncertain. to date, no study has concurrently evaluated renal outcomes with brain mri and continuous eeg in this context. prompted by the kidney disease: improving global outcomes (kdigo) aki guideline’s suggestion to consider a single prophylactic methylxanthine dose for term infants with perinatal asphyxia and by the extensive safety record of caffeine in neonatal care, our units adopted a protocol in 2019 to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg dose of caffeine citrate within 24 hours of birth to every infant with moderate or severe hie undergoing th. 20 this retrospective cohort study compares infants treated before and after that practice change to determine whether caffeine lowers aki incidence and improves early kidney markers without exacerbating cerebral injury assessed by brain mri and continuous eeg. back to top methods study design and setting we conducted a retrospective cohort study across three nicus in our enterprise—two level iii delivery-hospital units and one level iv regional referral centre. together, the network manages ≈10 000 deliveries each year, and th is available at all three sites, which share the same team of neonatologists, paediatric neurologists and epileptologists. study population infants born between 1 january 2013 and 31 december 2022 were eligible if they were ≥36 weeks gestation, weighed >2 kg, showed biochemical evidence of perinatal asphyxia (arterial or cord ph of 7.0 or less and/or a base deficit of greater than 16, or a ph between 7.01 and 7.15 and/or a base deficit between 10 and 15.9 accompanied by an apgar score of 5 or less at 10 min of life or prolonged resuscitation at birth defined as chest compressions and/or intubation or mask ventilation at 10 min of life) and had evidence of moderate or severe encephalopathy on neurological examination based on modified sarnat criteria (level of consciousness, spontaneous activity, posture, muscle tone, primitive reflexes and autonomic function). infants born with severe congenital malformations or chromosomal anomalies were excluded from the study. whole-body hypothermia was achieved using an arctic sun 5000 temperature management system to maintain oesophageal temperature at 33.5°c for 72 hours. this was followed by controlled rewarming at a rate of 0.5°c per hour until reaching normothermia at 37°c. 2 non-caffeine group versus caffeine group in 2019, our unit implemented a practice change of administering a single 20 mg/kg intravenous dose of caffeine for neonates diagnosed with moderate or severe hie within the first 24 hours of life as a potential renal protective measure. no maintenance doses were given and serum caffeine levels were not measured. all other aspects of supportive care including sedation/analgesia, anticonvulsant pathway, respiratory and fluid management, diuretic use and vasoactive protocols remained mostly unchanged across the study period. infants admitted before 2019 (2013–2018) who did not receive caffeine formed the non-caffeine group, whereas those admitted in 2019 or later (2019–2022), following the new protocol, formed the caffeine group. patient and public involvement patients and members of the public were not involved in the design, conduct, reporting or dissemination plans of this retrospective chart review study. the project used routinely collected, de-identified clinical data and received an institutional review board waiver of informed consent. data collection neonatal and maternal demographic characteristics and outcome data were obtained from electronic medical records. maternal and perinatal data included maternal age, gravidity/parity, mode of delivery, obstetric complications (sentinel events) such as placental abruption, cord prolapse, shoulder dystocia, uterine rupture, nuchal cord or head entrapment, umbilical-cord arterial ph and base deficit, apgar scores at 1, 5 and 10 min, first-hour arterial blood-gas results and admission lactate. neonatal demographics and illness-severity variables comprised sex, gestational age, birth weight and centile, hie severity (moderate or severe), exposure to vasoactive infusions in the first 24 hours, use of loop diuretics in the first 5 days and duration of mechanical ventilation. renal and fluid variables were collected for post-natal days (day of life) 1–5. serum creatinine (scr) and blood-urea nitrogen (bun) were measured daily. highest value recorded each day was analysed. uop during each of the first five post-natal days was calculated from weighed diapers and summarised as the average ml/kg/hour for the corresponding 24-hour interval. daily total fluid intake was retrieved from nutrition flow-sheets and analysed separately from uop. neurological variables brain mri was obtained after re-warming, typically on post-natal days 5–10, using standard neonatal protocol on a 3 t scanner (axial t1- and t2-weighted images plus diffusion-weighted and susceptibility-weighted imaging). clinical reports were reviewed retrospectively from the medical chart. any report describing injury patterns typical of hie (basal-ganglia/thalamic signal abnormality, loss of posterior-limb-internal-capsule signal, cortical or watershed injury, or restricted diffusion) was coded as abnormal , whereas scans without such findings were coded as normal . reports were authored in routine practice by paediatric neuroradiologists who had access to the medical chart. no secondary blinded scoring was undertaken. to our knowledge, mri hardware, acquisition parameters and reporting practices remained unchanged across the 2013–2022 study period. continuous multi-channel video-eeg began at th initiation and continued through re-warming plus the first 24 hours of normothermia (~96 hours) using a standard neonatal 10–20 montage. background in the first 24 hours was graded as normal, mildly discontinuous, moderately discontinuous or severe (burst-suppression, continuous low voltage or inactive) according to american clinical neurophysiology society terminology. 21 reports were generated by paediatric/neonatal neurologists as part of clinical care and readers were not blinded to chart data. seizures were categorised as eeg-only (electrographic event >10 s without clinical correlation), clinical-only (stereotyped clinical events that prompted anticonvulsant treatment but were not captured electrographically) or both (clinical events with concurrent eeg confirmation). nutrition and discharge variables comprised day to full oral feeds, need for tube feeding at discharge (nasogastric or gastrostomy), nicu length of stay (los) and in-hospital mortality. outcomes and definitions the primary outcome was the incidence of aki, defined based on criteria from the awaken study, which uses modified kdigo guidelines for neonates. 20 an infant was considered to have aki after the first 24 hours of life if either (1) increase in scr ≥0.3 mg/dl or 50% from the lowest previous nadir and/or (2) uop<1 ml/kg/hour averaged over 24 hours. severity was graded as stage 1 (scr rise≥0.3 mg/dl or ≥50%, or uop<1 ml/kg/hour for ≥24 hours), stage 2 (scr rise≥100% or uop<0.5 ml/kg/hour for ≥24 hours) and stage 3 (scr≥2.5 mg/dl, uop<0.3 ml/kg/hour for ≥24 hours, or initiation of renal-replacement therapy). serum creatine was measured using an enzymatic assay in our laboratory. secondary outcomes included trajectories of scr, bun and uop across the first five post-natal days, brain mri findings, early eeg background abnormalities, seizures (clinical/eeg), nicu length of nicu stay (los), duration of mechanical ventilation, mortality and need for tube (nasogastric or g tube) feeds at discharge. statistical analysis descriptive statistics, including medians and iqrs or means and sd, were used to summarise continuous variables, while categorical variables were expressed as counts and percentages. group comparisons between the caffeine and non-caffeine groups were conducted using two-sample t-tests or non-parametric wilcoxon rank-sum tests for continuous variables and χ 2 or fisher’s exact tests for categorical variables. subgroup analyses were conducted to examine differences in aki incidence, mri abnormalities and other outcomes by hie severity (moderate vs severe). all tests were two-sided, with a significance level set at 0.05. analyses were performed using sas v.9.4 (sas institute, cary, north carolina, usa). back to top results during the study period between january 2013 and december 2022, 85 infants were diagnosed with moderate or severe hie at our centre. there were 62 infants with moderate hie and 23 infants with severe hie. of the 85 infants included, 38 received caffeine and 47 did not. in the caffeine group, infants received caffeine at a median age of 6 hours after birth (iqr 2–24 hours). demographic and clinical characteristics the demographic characteristics of the mothers and infants in both groups were compared ( table 1 ). baseline maternal characteristics were similar in both groups, with no statistical significance. there were no significant differences in the rates of common perinatal complications between the two groups. additionally, there were no significant differences in the sex ratio of the neonates or the number of small-for-gestational-age neonates. notably, 1-minute and 5-minute apgar scores were higher in the caffeine group; however, 10-minute apgar scores were comparable between the two groups. the distribution of hie severity was balanced between groups, with a slightly higher proportion of severe hie cases in the non-caffeine group (33%) compared with the caffeine group (20%), with no statistical significance. table 1 view inline • open as popup baseline maternal and neonatal characteristics fluid discharge outcomes the two groups had no significant differences in the length of nicu stay. the median nicu los was comparable for both the caffeine and non-caffeine groups ( table 3 ). the rates of home discharge with tube feeding were similar for both groups. the mortality rate during hospitalisation was 2.6% in the caffeine and 10% in the non-caffeine groups, but this difference was not statistically significant. there were no significant differences in the duration of mechanical ventilation, length of nicu stays or need for tube feedings at discharge between the caffeine and non-caffeine groups in the moderate hie subgroup ( table 4 ). mortality rates were similar between the two groups. the duration of mechanical ventilation was significantly longer in the non-caffeine group (median of 5 days) compared with the caffeine group (median of 1 day) in the severe hie subgroup (p=0.02). however, no significant differences were observed in the length of nicu stay or the difference was not statistically significant. back to top discussion in this retrospective cohort, neonates with moderate or severe hie who received a single, protocol-driven caffeine dose during th did not show a reduction in aki (29% vs 47%), however exhibited lower scr and bun concentrations on postnatal days 3–5. taken together, these findings suggest that although caffeine may favourably influence early laboratory markers of kidney function, it did not confer a measurable clinical benefit with respect to aki in this population. conversely, infants in the caffeine group had higher rates of mri brain abnormalities consistent with hie compared with those in the non-caffeine group, particularly among infants with moderate hie. a distinct distribution of eeg background abnormalities was observed, with fewer severe but more mild/moderate patterns in the caffeine group. however, caffeine administration was not associated with significant differences in other clinical outcomes, such as seizure frequency, length of nicu stay or mortality. caffeine’s proposed mechanisms for renal protection include vasodilatory effects, which may enhance renal blood flow, and anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties that could mitigate renal injury from oxidative stress and inflammation in hypoxic neonates. 12 16 22 the significantly lower bun and scr levels observed in the caffeine group suggest that caffeine may improve renal function by increasing the glomerular filtration rate. 12 16 the overall aki incidence in our cohort (37%) parallels rates reported in other contemporary therapeutic-hypothermia cohorts that used neonatal kdigo criteria—34% in sweden, 38% in turkey and 45% in a north-american registry supporting the external validity of our renal findings. 5 23 24 notably, earlier randomised trials of aminophylline/theophylline in term hie reported significant short-term falls in creatinine and oliguria, 9–12 and a recent multicentre cohort of 4675 infants found no increase in mortality or major morbidities with methylxanthines use in neonates who underwent th. 12 our data extend this literature by showing that caffeine—the most widely used neonatal methylxanthine—improves biochemical renal indices yet does not translate into a lower aki rate when given as a single dose. multiple-dose regimens or therapeutic drug monitoring may be required to reproduce the renal benefits seen with aminophylline/theophylline. the higher rates of mri abnormalities observed in the caffeine group, particularly among infants with moderate hie, raise concern that adenosine-receptor blockade in an already hypoxic brain could intensify metabolic demand and potentiate tissue injury. 25–27 this interpretation must remain cautious for two reasons: clinical mri reports were not blinded to caffeine exposure, and inter-rater reliability was not assessed, leaving open the possibility of reporting bias. second, the absolute lesion burden we observed (60% in caffeine vs 36% in controls) still falls within the wide 30%–70% range documented in contemporary th cohorts, 2 28 29 indicating that our rate although higher does not represent an outlier. the eeg findings suggest a redistribution toward milder background patterns in caffeine-exposed neonates rather than an overall worsening of electrocortical activity. such a redistribution could reflect partial normalisation, random variation or subtle baseline differences not captured in our data; it is noteworthy that similar shifts toward less discontinuous eeg have been reported after caffeine in preterm studies without accompanying reductions in seizure burden. 30 whether the observed shift represents a beneficial partial normalisation of background activity or reflects baseline differences between cohorts remains unclear, mainly because it was not accompanied by fewer seizures or mri lesions. despite these findings in imaging and eeg, caffeine administration was not associated with significant differences in other short-term clinical outcomes such as nicu los or mortality in either the moderate or severe hie groups. while caffeine may influence some neuroimaging markers, these changes may not translate into observable short-term clinical outcomes, possibly due to the complex nature of hie and the multifactorial interventions involved in its management. 31 the sample size also limited our ability to detect differences in outcomes. the shorter duration of mechanical ventilation in the caffeine group among infants with severe hie suggests a potential benefit of caffeine related to respiratory support. however, this difference in ventilation duration may be influenced by a small sample size and should be interpreted with caution. the strengths of the study include a well-defined cohort of neonates treated with standardised th protocols and a consistent caffeine administration to all eligible infants born between 2019 and 2022, minimising potential selection bias. additionally, this study looked at the renal and short-term neurological outcomes by assessing mri brain and eeg background abnormalities. also, this study is one of the few examining the effects of caffeine in neonates with hie treated with th, an area that remains underexplored despite the need for effective adjunct therapies in this vulnerable population. nonetheless, several limitations should be considered. our retrospective design and modest sample size may have limited our ability to detect subtle effects. the lack of protein intake and nutritional status data limits our ability to interpret the lower bun levels observed in the caffeine group, as variations in dietary protein could influence bun levels. additionally, we relied on standard renal markers like scr and bun, which might not fully capture renal function nuances in neonates. the absence of long-term neurodevelopmental data prevents assessment of whether observed mri or eeg changes have lasting neurodevelopmental consequences. clinical mri reports were generated by neuroradiologists with access to the medical record, and inter-rater reliability was not assessed; likewise, eeg tracings were interpreted by several paediatric neurologists without formal assessment of inter-reader agreement, introducing additional potential for reporting bias. further, our unit adopted a single 20 mg/kg caffeine load extrapolated from preterm apnoea protocols; we did not measure serum caffeine concentrations or explore repeated dosing. consequently, we cannot determine whether the selected dose provided sufficient systemic exposure for renal benefit or whether alternative dosing regimens might yield a different renal–neurological risk profile. future studies should consider larger sample sizes, more extensive dosing protocols with drug level monitoring, additional renal biomarkers, detailed nutritional assessments and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up to clarify caffeine’s safety and efficacy in this population. back to top conclusion in summary, a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine dose given during th for moderate or severe hie lowered scr and bun but did not lessen the incidence or severity of aki. moreover, caffeine-exposed infants displayed a higher burden of mri lesions and a shift towards milder early eeg backgrounds. these retrospective findings underscore the need for prospective, dose-controlled trials—including pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up—to clarify caffeine’s renal effects and establish its neurologic safety in self.__next_f.push([1,"8:null\ne:t7cf,objective to evaluate the association of caffeine with renal and other short-term clinical outcomes in neonates with moderate or severe hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) undergoing therapeutic hypothermia (th).study design this retrospective cohort study included neonates born at ≥36 weeks gestational age with moderate or severe hie treated with th at our centre between january 2013 and december 2022. in 2019, there was a practice change to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine citrate dose for moderate/severe hie, forming two cohorts (non-caffeine vs caffeine). the primary outcome was acute kidney injury (aki), defined by modified kidney disease: improving global outcomes criteria. secondary outcomes included daily serum creatinine, blood-urea nitrogen (bun), urine output, hie-pattern lesion on brain-mri, early eeg background grade, seizures, duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay, tube-feeding at discharge and in-hospital mortality.results 85 neonates met the inclusion criteria; 38 received caffeine, and 47 did not. aki incidence was lower in the caffeine group (29% vs 47%), although not statistically significant (p=0.09). bun levels and serum creatinine levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 3–5 (p\u003c0.05). mri abnormalities consistent with hie were more frequent in the caffeine group (60% vs 36%, p=0.028), particularly in infants with moderate hie (p=0.004). eeg background profiles differed, with caffeine-exposed neonates displaying fewer severe (34% vs 65%) and more mild-to-moderate patterns. no significant differences were noted in other secondary outcomes.conclusion caffeine during th lowered serum creatinine and bun but did not significantly reduce aki and was associated with higher rates of mri lesions. prospective, dose-controlled trials with pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up are needed to clarify caffeine’s renal benefits and neurological safety in neonatal hie.f:t7cf,objective to evaluate the as"]) self.__next_f.push([1,"sociation of caffeine with renal and other short-term clinical outcomes neonates with moderate or severe hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) undergoing therapeutic hypothermia (th).study design this retrospective cohort study included neonates born at ≥36 weeks gestational age with moderate or severe hie treated with th at our centre between january 2013 and december 2022. in 2019, there was a practice change to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine citrate dose for moderate/severe hie, forming two cohorts (non-caffeine vs caffeine). the primary outcome was acute kidney injury (aki), defined by modified kidney disease: improving global outcomes criteria. secondary outcomes included daily serum creatinine, blood-urea nitrogen (bun), urine output, hie-pattern lesion on brain-mri, early eeg background grade, seizures, duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay, tube-feeding at discharge and in-hospital mortality.results 85 neonates met the inclusion criteria; 38 received caffeine, and 47 did not. aki incidence was lower in the caffeine group (29% vs 47%), although not statistically significant (p=0.09). bun levels and serum creatinine levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 3–5 (p\u003c0.05). mri abnormalities consistent with hie were more frequent in the caffeine group (60% vs 36%, p=0.028), particularly in infants with moderate hie (p=0.004). eeg background profiles differed, with caffeine-exposed neonates displaying fewer severe (34% vs 65%) and more mild-to-moderate patterns. no significant differences were noted in other secondary outcomes.conclusion caffeine during th lowered serum creatinine and bun but did not significantly reduce aki and was associated with higher rates of mri lesions. prospective, dose-controlled trials with pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up are needed to clarify caffeine’s renal benefits and neurological safety in neonatal hie.\",\"datepublished\":\"2025-09-23\",\"ispartof\":{\"@type\":\"publicationissue\",\"issuenumber\":\"1\",\"pagination\":\"e003720\",\"ispartof\":{\"@type\":\"publicationvolume\",\"volumenumber\":\"9\",\"ispartof\":{\"@type\":\"periodical\",\"name\":\"bmj paediatrics open\"}}},\"url\":\"https://bmjpaedsopen.bmj.com/content/9/1/e003720\",\"description\":\"what is already known on this topic caffeine is widely used in preterm infants and observationally linked to less acute kidney injury (aki), but its renal and neurological effects during therapeutic hypothermia (th) for term hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) are unknown.\"}"]) self.__next_f.push([1,"1c:[[\"department of pediatrics, division of neonataology, cleveland clinic children’s hospital, cleveland, ohio, usa\",1],[\"department of pediatric neurology, cleveland clinic children’s hospital, cleveland, ohio, usa\",2],[\"quantitative health science, cleveland clinic, cleveland, ohio, usa\",3]]\n22:t669,nonetheless, several limitations should be considered. our retrospective design and modest sample size may have limited our ability to detect subtle effects. the lack of protein intake and nutritional status data limits our ability to interpret the lower bun levels observed in the caffeine group, as variations in dietary protein could influence bun levels. additionally, we relied on standard renal markers like scr and bun, which might not fully capture renal function nuances in neonates. the absence of long-term neurodevelopmental data prevents assessment of whether observed mri or eeg changes have lasting neurodevelopmental consequences. clinical mri reports were generated by neuroradiologists with access to the medical record, and inter-rater reliability was not assessed; likewise, eeg tracings were interpreted by several paediatric neurologists without formal assessment of inter-reader agreement, introducing additional potential for reporting bias. further, our unit adopted a single 20 mg/kg caffeine load extrapolated from preterm apnoea protocols; we did not measure serum caffeine concentrations or explore repeated dosing. consequently, we cannot determine whether the selected dose provided sufficient systemic exposure for renal benefit or whether alternative dosing regimens might yield a different renal–neurological risk profile. future studies should consider larger sample sizes, more extensive dosing protocols with drug level monitoring, additional renal biomarkers, detailed nutritional assessments and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up to clarify caffeine’s safety and efficacy in this design\"}],\" this retrospective cohort study included neonates born at ≥36 weeks gestational age with moderate or severe hie treated with th at our centre between january 2013 and december 2022. in 2019, there was a practice change to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine citrate dose for moderate/severe hie, forming two cohorts (non-caffeine vs caffeine). the primary outcome was acute kidney injury (aki), defined by modified kidney disease: improving global outcomes criteria. secondary outcomes included daily serum creatinine, blood-urea nitrogen (bun), urine output, hie-pattern lesion on brain-mri, early eeg background grade, seizures, duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay, tube-feeding at discharge and in-hospital 85 neonates met the inclusion criteria; 38 received caffeine, and 47 did not. aki incidence was lower in the caffeine group (29% vs 47%), although not statistically significant (p=0.09). bun levels and serum creatinine levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 3–5 (p\u003c0.05). mri abnormalities consistent with hie were more frequent in the caffeine group (60% vs 36%, p=0.028), particularly in infants with moderate hie (p=0.004). eeg background profiles differed, with caffeine-exposed neonates displaying fewer severe (34% vs 65%) and more mild-to-moderate patterns. no significant differences were noted in other secondary outcomes.\"]}]}],[\"$\",\"div\",\"4\",{\"id\":\"sec-4\",\"classname\":\"subsection\",\"children\":[\"$\",\"p\",null,{\"id\":\"p-5\",\"children\":[[\"$\",\"strong\",\"0\",{\"children\":\"conclusion\"}],\" caffeine during th lowered serum creatinine and bun but did not significantly reduce aki and was associated with higher rates of mri lesions. prospective, dose-controlled trials with pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up are needed to clarify caffeine’s renal benefits and neurological safety in neonatal encephalopathy (hie) affects approximately 1–4 per 1000 live births in high-resource settings and remains a major cause of neonatal death and lifelong neurodisability.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-1-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-1\",\"children\":\"1\"}],\" therapeutic hypothermia (th) initiated within 6 hours of birth improves survival and neurodevelopmental outcomes, yet does not prevent multisystem sequelae.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-2-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-2\",\"children\":\"2\"}],\" acute kidney injury (aki) occurs in 20%–40% of infants with hie who underwent th and is independently associated with higher mortality, longer intensive-care stay and poorer cognitive scores at school age.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"5\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-3-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-3\",\"children\":\"3–5\"}],\" furthermore, neonates with hie who develop aki are at an increased risk of chronic kidney disease in later childhood and adolescence.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"7\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-6-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-6\",\"children\":\"6\"}],\" a single-centre cohort study demonstrated that neonatal aki in hie is associated with abnormal brain mri findings and lower bayley developmental scores.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"9\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-7-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-7\",\"children\":\"7 8\"}],\" despite the clear implication of aki on mortality and morbidity, there are currently limited therapeutic interventions available.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"2\",{\"id\":\"p-10\",\"children\":[\"several studies have investigated the potential of methylxanthines, including aminophylline and theophylline, to improve renal outcomes in neonates.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-9-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-9\",\"children\":\"9–12\"}],\" both drugs have demonstrated benefits in enhancing urine output (uop) and reducing the incidence of aki, likely through their renal vasodilatory and diuretic effects.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-13-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-13\",\"children\":\"13\"}],\" however, due to limited data on side effect profiles and pharmacokinetics of aminophylline and theophylline in neonates, they are infrequently used in clinical practice. a recent multicentre cohort of 4675 infants showed that methylxanthine exposure in neonates with hie who underwent th did not increase mortality or major morbidities, renewing interest in this drug class.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"5\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-12-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-12\",\"children\":\"12\"}]]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"p-11\",\"children\":[\"caffeine, another methylxanthine, is well tolerated in preterm infants and is widely used in neonatal intensive care units (nicus) for apnoea of prematurity.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-14-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-14\",\"children\":\"14 15\"}],\" experimental data show that adenosine-a1 receptor antagonism enhances glomerular filtration and natriuresis, while anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects may mitigate ischaemia–reperfusion injury.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-16-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-16\",\"children\":\"16\"}]]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"4\",{\"id\":\"p-12\",\"children\":[\"observational studies in very-low-birth-weight cohorts link early caffeine exposure to a lower aki risk,\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-17-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-17\",\"children\":\"17 18\"}],\" and a phase-i pharmacokinetic study in term neonates demonstrated predictable distribution during th.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-19-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-19\",\"children\":\"19\"}],\" because caffeine crosses the blood brain barrier and may raise cerebral metabolic demand, its net neurological impact in already-injured term brains remains uncertain. to date, no study has concurrently evaluated renal outcomes with brain mri and continuous eeg in this context.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"5\",{\"id\":\"p-13\",\"children\":[\"prompted by the kidney disease: improving global outcomes (kdigo) aki guideline’s suggestion to consider a single prophylactic methylxanthine dose for term infants with perinatal asphyxia and by the extensive safety record of caffeine in neonatal care, our units adopted a protocol in 2019 to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg dose of caffeine citrate within 24 hours of birth to every infant with moderate or severe hie undergoing th.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-20-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-20\",\"children\":\"20\"}],\" this retrospective cohort study compares infants treated before and after 37°c.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-2-2\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-2\",\"children\":\"2\"}]]}]]}],[\"$\",\"div\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"sec-12\",\"classname\":\"subsection\",\"children\":[[\"$\",\"h3\",\"0\",{\"children\":\"non-caffeine all other aspects of supportive care including sedation/analgesia, anticonvulsant pathway, respiratory and fluid management, diuretic use and vasoactive protocols remained mostly unchanged across the variables\"}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"p-23\",\"children\":[\"brain mri was obtained after re-warming, typically on post-natal days 5–10, using standard neonatal protocol on a 3 t scanner (axial t1- and t2-weighted images plus diffusion-weighted and susceptibility-weighted imaging). clinical reports were reviewed retrospectively from the medical chart. any report describing injury patterns typical of hie (basal-ganglia/thalamic signal abnormality, loss of posterior-limb-internal-capsule signal, cortical or watershed injury, or restricted diffusion) was coded as \",[\"$\",\"em\",\"1\",{\"children\":\"abnormal\"}],\", whereas scans without such findings were coded as \",[\"$\",\"em\",\"3\",{\"children\":\"normal\"}],\". reports were authored in routine practice by paediatric neuroradiologists who had access to the medical chart. no secondary blinded scoring was undertaken. to our knowledge, mri hardware, acquisition parameters and reporting practices remained unchanged across the 2013–2022 study period. continuous multi-channel video-eeg began at th initiation and continued through re-warming plus the first 24 hours of normothermia (~96 this retrospective cohort, neonates with moderate or severe hie who received a single, protocol-driven caffeine dose during th did not show a reduction in aki (29% vs 47%), however exhibited lower scr and bun concentrations on postnatal days 3–5. taken together, these findings suggest that although caffeine may favourably influence early laboratory markers of kidney function, it did not confer a measurable clinical benefit with respect to aki in this population. conversely, infants in the caffeine group had higher rates of mri brain abnormalities consistent with hie compared with those in the non-caffeine group, particularly among infants with moderate hie. a distinct distribution of eeg background abnormalities was observed, with fewer severe but more mild/moderate patterns in the caffeine group. however, caffeine administration was not associated with significant differences in other clinical outcomes, such as seizure frequency, length of nicu stay or mortality.\"}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"2\",{\"id\":\"p-55\",\"children\":[\"caffeine’s proposed mechanisms for renal protection include vasodilatory effects, which may enhance renal blood flow, and neonates.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-12-2\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-12\",\"children\":\"12 16 22\"}],\" the significantly lower bun and scr levels observed in the caffeine group suggest that caffeine may improve renal function by increasing the glomerular filtration rate.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-12-3\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-12\",\"children\":\"12 16\"}]]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"p-56\",\"children\":[\"the overall aki incidence in our cohort (37%) parallels rates reported in other contemporary therapeutic-hypothermia cohorts that used neonatal kdigo criteria—34% in sweden, 38% in turkey and 45% in a north-american registry supporting the external validity of our renal findings.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-5-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-5\",\"children\":\"5 23 24\"}],\" notably, earlier randomised trials of aminophylline/theophylline in term hie reported significant short-term falls in creatinine and oliguria,\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-9-2\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-9\",\"children\":\"9–12\"}],\" and a recent multicentre cohort of 4675 infants found no increase in mortality or major morbidities with methylxanthines use in neonates who underwent th.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"5\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-12-4\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-12\",\"children\":\"12\"}],\" our data extend this literature by showing that caffeine—the most widely used neonatal methylxanthine—improves biochemical renal indices yet does not translate into a lower aki rate when given as a single dose. multiple-dose regimens or therapeutic drug monitoring may be required to reproduce the renal benefits seen with aminophylline/theophylline.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"4\",{\"id\":\"p-57\",\"children\":[\"the higher rates of mri abnormalities observed in the caffeine injury.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-25-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-25\",\"children\":\"25–27\"}],\" this interpretation must remain cautious for two reasons: clinical mri reports were not blinded to caffeine exposure, and inter-rater reliability was not assessed, leaving open the possibility of reporting bias. second, the absolute lesion burden we observed (60% in caffeine vs 36% in controls) still falls within the wide 30%–70% range documented in contemporary th cohorts,\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-2-3\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-2\",\"children\":\"2 28 29\"}],\" indicating that our rate although higher does not represent an similar shifts toward less discontinuous eeg have been reported after caffeine in preterm studies without accompanying reductions in seizure burden.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-30-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-30\",\"children\":\"30\"}],\" whether the observed shift represents a beneficial partial lesions.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"6\",{\"id\":\"p-59\",\"children\":[\"despite these findings in imaging and eeg, caffeine administration was not associated with significant differences in other short-term short-term clinical outcomes, possibly due to the complex nature of hie and the multifactorial interventions involved in its management.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-31-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-31\",\"children\":\"31\"}],\" the sample size also limited our ability to detect differences in hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) affects approximately 1–4 per 1000 live births in high-resource settings and remains a major cause of neonatal death and lifelong neurodisability. 1 therapeutic hypothermia (th) initiated within 6 hours of birth improves survival and neurodevelopmental outcomes, yet does not prevent multisystem sequelae. 2 acute kidney injury (aki) occurs in 20%–40% of infants with hie who underwent th and is independently associated with higher mortality, longer intensive-care stay and poorer cognitive scores at school age. 3–5 furthermore, neonates with hie who develop aki are at an increased risk of chronic kidney disease in later childhood and adolescence. 6 a single-centre cohort study demonstrated that neonatal aki in hie is associated with abnormal brain mri findings and lower bayley developmental scores. 7 8 despite the clear implication of aki on mortality and morbidity, there are currently limited therapeutic interventions available. several studies have investigated the potential of methylxanthines, including aminophylline and theophylline, to improve renal outcomes in neonates. 9–12 both drugs have demonstrated benefits in enhancing urine output (uop) and reducing the incidence of aki, likely through their renal vasodilatory and diuretic effects. 13 however, due to limited data on side effect profiles and pharmacokinetics of aminophylline and theophylline in neonates, they are infrequently used in clinical practice. a recent multicentre cohort of 4675 infants showed that methylxanthine exposure in neonates with hie who underwent th did not increase mortality or major morbidities, renewing interest in this drug class. 12 caffeine, another methylxanthine, is well tolerated in preterm infants and is widely used in neonatal intensive care units (nicus) for apnoea of prematurity. 14 15 experimental data show that adenosine-a1 receptor antagonism enhances glomerular filtration and natriuresis, while anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects may mitigate ischaemia–reperfusion injury. 16 observational studies in very-low-birth-weight cohorts link early caffeine exposure to a lower aki risk, 17 18 and a phase-i pharmacokinetic study in term neonates demonstrated predictable distribution during th. 19 because caffeine crosses the blood brain barrier and may raise cerebral metabolic demand, its net neurological impact in already-injured term brains remains uncertain. to date, no study has concurrently evaluated renal outcomes with brain mri and continuous eeg in this context. prompted by the kidney disease: improving global outcomes (kdigo) aki guideline’s suggestion to consider a single prophylactic methylxanthine dose for term infants with perinatal asphyxia and by the extensive safety record of caffeine in neonatal care, our units adopted a protocol in 2019 to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg dose of caffeine citrate within 24 hours of birth to every infant with moderate or severe hie undergoing th. 20 this retrospective cohort study compares infants treated before and after that practice change to determine whether caffeine lowers aki incidence and improves early kidney markers without exacerbating cerebral injury assessed by brain mri and continuous eeg. back to top methods study design and setting we conducted a retrospective cohort study across three nicus in our enterprise—two level iii delivery-hospital units and one level iv regional referral centre. together, the network manages ≈10 000 deliveries each year, and th is available at all three sites, which share the same team of neonatologists, paediatric neurologists and epileptologists. study population infants born between 1 january 2013 and 31 december 2022 were eligible if they were ≥36 weeks gestation, weighed >2 kg, showed biochemical evidence of perinatal asphyxia (arterial or cord ph of 7.0 or less and/or a base deficit of greater than 16, or a ph between 7.01 and 7.15 and/or a base deficit between 10 and 15.9 accompanied by an apgar score of 5 or less at 10 min of life or prolonged resuscitation at birth defined as chest compressions and/or intubation or mask ventilation at 10 min of life) and had evidence of moderate or severe encephalopathy on neurological examination based on modified sarnat criteria (level of consciousness, spontaneous activity, posture, muscle tone, primitive reflexes and autonomic function). infants born with severe congenital malformations or chromosomal anomalies were excluded from the study. whole-body hypothermia was achieved using an arctic sun 5000 temperature management system to maintain oesophageal temperature at 33.5°c for 72 hours. this was followed by controlled rewarming at a rate of 0.5°c per hour until reaching normothermia at 37°c. 2 non-caffeine group versus caffeine group in 2019, our unit implemented a practice change of administering a single 20 mg/kg intravenous dose of caffeine for neonates diagnosed with moderate or severe hie within the first 24 hours of life as a potential renal protective measure. no maintenance doses were given and serum caffeine levels were not measured. all other aspects of supportive care including sedation/analgesia, anticonvulsant pathway, respiratory and fluid management, diuretic use and vasoactive protocols remained mostly unchanged across the study period. infants admitted before 2019 (2013–2018) who did not receive caffeine formed the non-caffeine group, whereas those admitted in 2019 or later (2019–2022), following the new protocol, formed the caffeine group. patient and public involvement patients and members of the public were not involved in the design, conduct, reporting or dissemination plans of this retrospective chart review study. the project used routinely collected, de-identified clinical data and received an institutional review board waiver of informed consent. data collection neonatal and maternal demographic characteristics and outcome data were obtained from electronic medical records. maternal and perinatal data included maternal age, gravidity/parity, mode of delivery, obstetric complications (sentinel events) such as placental abruption, cord prolapse, shoulder dystocia, uterine rupture, nuchal cord or head entrapment, umbilical-cord arterial ph and base deficit, apgar scores at 1, 5 and 10 min, first-hour arterial blood-gas results and admission lactate. neonatal demographics and illness-severity variables comprised sex, gestational age, birth weight and centile, hie severity (moderate or severe), exposure to vasoactive infusions in the first 24 hours, use of loop diuretics in the first 5 days and duration of mechanical ventilation. renal and fluid variables were collected for post-natal days (day of life) 1–5. serum creatinine (scr) and blood-urea nitrogen (bun) were measured daily. highest value recorded each day was analysed. uop during each of the first five post-natal days was calculated from weighed diapers and summarised as the average ml/kg/hour for the corresponding 24-hour interval. daily total fluid intake was retrieved from nutrition flow-sheets and analysed separately from uop. neurological variables brain mri was obtained after re-warming, typically on post-natal days 5–10, using standard neonatal protocol on a 3 t scanner (axial t1- and t2-weighted images plus diffusion-weighted and susceptibility-weighted imaging). clinical reports were reviewed retrospectively from the medical chart. any report describing injury patterns typical of hie (basal-ganglia/thalamic signal abnormality, loss of posterior-limb-internal-capsule signal, cortical or watershed injury, or restricted diffusion) was coded as abnormal , whereas scans without such findings were coded as normal . reports were authored in routine practice by paediatric neuroradiologists who had access to the medical chart. no secondary blinded scoring was undertaken. to our knowledge, mri hardware, acquisition parameters and reporting practices remained unchanged across the 2013–2022 study period. continuous multi-channel video-eeg began at th initiation and continued through re-warming plus the first 24 hours of normothermia (~96 hours) using a standard neonatal 10–20 montage. background in the first 24 hours was graded as normal, mildly discontinuous, moderately discontinuous or severe (burst-suppression, continuous low voltage or inactive) according to american clinical neurophysiology society terminology. 21 reports were generated by paediatric/neonatal neurologists as part of clinical care and readers were not blinded to chart data. seizures were categorised as eeg-only (electrographic event >10 s without clinical correlation), clinical-only (stereotyped clinical events that prompted anticonvulsant treatment but were not captured electrographically) or both (clinical events with concurrent eeg confirmation). nutrition and discharge variables comprised day to full oral feeds, need for tube feeding at discharge (nasogastric or gastrostomy), nicu length of stay (los) and in-hospital mortality. outcomes and definitions the primary outcome was the incidence of aki, defined based on criteria from the awaken study, which uses modified kdigo guidelines for neonates. 20 an infant was considered to have aki after the first 24 hours of life if either (1) increase in scr ≥0.3 mg/dl or 50% from the lowest previous nadir and/or (2) uop<1 ml/kg/hour averaged over 24 hours. severity was graded as stage 1 (scr rise≥0.3 mg/dl or ≥50%, or uop<1 ml/kg/hour for ≥24 hours), stage 2 (scr rise≥100% or uop<0.5 ml/kg/hour for ≥24 hours) and stage 3 (scr≥2.5 mg/dl, uop<0.3 ml/kg/hour for ≥24 hours, or initiation of renal-replacement therapy). serum creatine was measured using an enzymatic assay in our laboratory. secondary outcomes included trajectories of scr, bun and uop across the first five post-natal days, brain mri findings, early eeg background abnormalities, seizures (clinical/eeg), nicu length of nicu stay (los), duration of mechanical ventilation, mortality and need for tube (nasogastric or g tube) feeds at discharge. statistical analysis descriptive statistics, including medians and iqrs or means and sd, were used to summarise continuous variables, while categorical variables were expressed as counts and percentages. group comparisons between the caffeine and non-caffeine groups were conducted using two-sample t-tests or non-parametric wilcoxon rank-sum tests for continuous variables and χ 2 or fisher’s exact tests for categorical variables. subgroup analyses were conducted to examine differences in aki incidence, mri abnormalities and other outcomes by hie severity (moderate vs severe). all tests were two-sided, with a significance level set at 0.05. analyses were performed using sas v.9.4 (sas institute, cary, north carolina, usa). back to top results during the study period between january 2013 and december 2022, 85 infants were diagnosed with moderate or severe hie at our centre. there were 62 infants with moderate hie and 23 infants with severe hie. of the 85 infants included, 38 received caffeine and 47 did not. in the caffeine group, infants received caffeine at a median age of 6 hours after birth (iqr 2–24 hours). demographic and clinical characteristics the demographic characteristics of the mothers and infants in both groups were compared ( table 1 ). baseline maternal characteristics were similar in both groups, with no statistical significance. there were no significant differences in the rates of common perinatal complications between the two groups. additionally, there were no significant differences in the sex ratio of the neonates or the number of small-for-gestational-age neonates. notably, 1-minute and 5-minute apgar scores were higher in the caffeine group; however, 10-minute apgar scores were comparable between the two groups. the distribution of hie severity was balanced between groups, with a slightly higher proportion of severe hie cases in the non-caffeine group (33%) compared with the caffeine group (20%), with no statistical significance. table 1 view inline • open as popup baseline maternal and neonatal characteristics fluid management and kidney function the incidence of neonatal aki was 29% in the caffeine group and 47% in the non-caffeine group, though not statistically significant (p=0.09). most cases of aki were classified as stage i in both groups (82% vs 73%), and there were no significant differences in the distribution of aki stages between the groups. subgroup analysis by hie severity showed no significant difference in the incidence of aki between caffeine and non-caffeine groups in either moderate or severe hie subgroups. total fluid volumes administered were similar between the two groups over the first 2 days of life. infants in the caffeine group received higher fluid intake on days 3–5 compared with the non-caffeine group (p<0.05). uop was comparable between the two groups ( figure 1 ). median scr levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 3–5 (p<0.05) ( table 2 ). median bun levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 1–5 (p<0.05). mean serum creatinine and bun values consistently trended lower in the caffeine group throughout the 5‐day observation period ( figures 2 and 3 ). loop-diuretic use in the first five post-natal days was uncommon and comparable between groups: 4/47 (9%) non-caffeine versus 3/38 (8%) caffeine (p=0.88) figure 1 request permissions urine output comparison between caffeine and non-caffeine groups. daily mean urine output (ml/kg/hour±95% ci) during post-natal days 1–5 in cooled neonates with hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy, comparing the non-caffeine cohort (blue, solid circles) with the caffeine cohort (orange, dotted triangles). dol, day of life. figure 2 request permissions serum creatinine trajectories of caffeine and non-caffeine groups. daily mean serum creatinine (mg/dl±95% ci) during post-natal days 1–5 in cooled neonates with hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy, comparing the non-caffeine cohort (blue, solid circles) with the caffeine cohort (orange, dotted triangles). figure 3 request permissions blood urea nitrogen (bun) trajectories of caffeine and non-caffeine groups. daily mean blood-urea nitrogen (mg/dl±95% ci) during post-natal days 1–5 in cooled neonates with hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy, comparing the non-caffeine cohort (blue, solid circles) with the caffeine cohort (orange, dotted triangles). table 2 view inline • open as popup fluid management and renal function neuroimaging and neurological outcomes brain mri findings consistent with hie were more common in the caffeine group compared with the non-caffeine group (60% vs 36%, p=0.028) ( table 3 ). the most common mri brain abnormalities observed were cortical and white matter injury in both groups. subgroup analysis of the severity showed that this difference was significant in the moderate hie subgroup with mri brain findings of hie observed in 60% of the caffeine group and 23% of the non-caffeine group (p=0.004) ( table 4 ) while no significant difference between the caffeine and non-caffeine group was noted in the severe hie subgroup ( table 5 ). the distribution of eeg background grades differed significantly between groups (p=0.008). caffeine-exposed infants had fewer severe backgrounds (34% vs 65%) but higher proportions of mild (29% vs 10%) and moderate (34% vs 15%) patterns ( table 3 ). this distribution indicates a shift toward milder eeg abnormalities among caffeine-treated infants. subgroup analysis did not show any significant difference in the severity of eeg background in the first 24 hours in moderate or severe hie. the incidence of seizures (clinical or eeg confirmed) was comparable in both groups with no statistically significant difference (40% vs 48%). table 3 view inline • open as popup secondary outcome measures of the whole study population table 4 view inline • open as popup outcomes of moderate hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) table 5 view inline • open as popup outcomes of severe hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) discharge outcomes the two groups had no significant differences in the length of nicu stay. the median nicu los was comparable for both the caffeine and non-caffeine groups ( table 3 ). the rates of home discharge with tube feeding were similar for both groups. the mortality rate during hospitalisation was 2.6% in the caffeine and 10% in the non-caffeine groups, but this difference was not statistically significant. there were no significant differences in the duration of mechanical ventilation, length of nicu stays or need for tube feedings at discharge between the caffeine and non-caffeine groups in the moderate hie subgroup ( table 4 ). mortality rates were similar between the two groups. the duration of mechanical ventilation was significantly longer in the non-caffeine group (median of 5 days) compared with the caffeine group (median of 1 day) in the severe hie subgroup (p=0.02). however, no significant differences were observed in the length of nicu stay or the discharge status related to tube feeding between the groups (p>0.05). mortality during hospitalisation was higher in the non-caffeine group (25%) compared with the caffeine group (0%), but this difference was not statistically significant. back to top discussion in this retrospective cohort, neonates with moderate or severe hie who received a single, protocol-driven caffeine dose during th did not show a reduction in aki (29% vs 47%), however exhibited lower scr and bun concentrations on postnatal days 3–5. taken together, these findings suggest that although caffeine may favourably influence early laboratory markers of kidney function, it did not confer a measurable clinical benefit with respect to aki in this population. conversely, infants in the caffeine group had higher rates of mri brain abnormalities consistent with hie compared with those in the non-caffeine group, particularly among infants with moderate hie. a distinct distribution of eeg background abnormalities was observed, with fewer severe but more mild/moderate patterns in the caffeine group. however, caffeine administration was not associated with significant differences in other clinical outcomes, such as seizure frequency, length of nicu stay or mortality. caffeine’s proposed mechanisms for renal protection include vasodilatory effects, which may enhance renal blood flow, and anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties that could mitigate renal injury from oxidative stress and inflammation in hypoxic neonates. 12 16 22 the significantly lower bun and scr levels observed in the caffeine group suggest that caffeine may improve renal function by increasing the glomerular filtration rate. 12 16 the overall aki incidence in our cohort (37%) parallels rates reported in other contemporary therapeutic-hypothermia cohorts that used neonatal kdigo criteria—34% in sweden, 38% in turkey and 45% in a north-american registry supporting the external validity of our renal findings. 5 23 24 notably, earlier randomised trials of aminophylline/theophylline in term hie reported significant short-term falls in creatinine and oliguria, 9–12 and a recent multicentre cohort of 4675 infants found no increase in mortality or major morbidities with methylxanthines use in neonates who underwent th. 12 our data extend this literature by showing that caffeine—the most widely used neonatal methylxanthine—improves biochemical renal indices yet does not translate into a lower aki rate when given as a single dose. multiple-dose regimens or therapeutic drug monitoring may be required to reproduce the renal benefits seen with aminophylline/theophylline. the higher rates of mri abnormalities observed in the caffeine group, particularly among infants with moderate hie, raise concern that adenosine-receptor blockade in an already hypoxic brain could intensify metabolic demand and potentiate tissue injury. 25–27 this interpretation must remain cautious for two reasons: clinical mri reports were not blinded to caffeine exposure, and inter-rater reliability was not assessed, leaving open the possibility of reporting bias. second, the absolute lesion burden we observed (60% in caffeine vs 36% in controls) still falls within the wide 30%–70% range documented in contemporary th cohorts, 2 28 29 indicating that our rate although higher does not represent an outlier. the eeg findings suggest a redistribution toward milder background patterns in caffeine-exposed neonates rather than an overall worsening of electrocortical activity. such a redistribution could reflect partial normalisation, random variation or subtle baseline differences not captured in our data; it is noteworthy that similar shifts toward less discontinuous eeg have been reported after caffeine in preterm studies without accompanying reductions in seizure burden. 30 whether the observed shift represents a beneficial partial normalisation of background activity or reflects baseline differences between cohorts remains unclear, mainly because it was not accompanied by fewer seizures or mri lesions. despite these findings in imaging and eeg, caffeine administration was not associated with significant differences in other short-term clinical outcomes such as nicu los or mortality in either the moderate or severe hie groups. while caffeine may influence some neuroimaging markers, these changes may not translate into observable short-term clinical outcomes, possibly due to the complex nature of hie and the multifactorial interventions involved in its management. 31 the sample size also limited our ability to detect differences in outcomes. the shorter duration of mechanical ventilation in the caffeine group among infants with severe hie suggests a potential benefit of caffeine related to respiratory support. however, this difference in ventilation duration may be influenced by a small sample size and should be interpreted with caution. the strengths of the study include a well-defined cohort of neonates treated with standardised th protocols and a consistent caffeine administration to all eligible infants born between 2019 and 2022, minimising potential selection bias. additionally, this study looked at the renal and short-term neurological outcomes by assessing mri brain and eeg background abnormalities. also, this study is one of the few examining the effects of caffeine in neonates with hie treated with th, an area that remains underexplored despite the need for effective adjunct therapies in this vulnerable population. nonetheless, several limitations should be considered. our retrospective design and modest sample size may have limited our ability to detect subtle effects. the lack of protein intake and nutritional status data limits our ability to interpret the lower bun levels observed in the caffeine group, as variations in dietary protein could influence bun levels. additionally, we relied on standard renal markers like scr and bun, which might not fully capture renal function nuances in neonates. the absence of long-term neurodevelopmental data prevents assessment of whether observed mri or eeg changes have lasting neurodevelopmental consequences. clinical mri reports were generated by neuroradiologists with access to the medical record, and inter-rater reliability was not assessed; likewise, eeg tracings were interpreted by several paediatric neurologists without formal assessment of inter-reader agreement, introducing additional potential for reporting bias. further, our unit adopted a single 20 mg/kg caffeine load extrapolated from preterm apnoea protocols; we did not measure serum caffeine concentrations or explore repeated dosing. consequently, we cannot determine whether the selected dose provided sufficient systemic exposure for renal benefit or whether alternative dosing regimens might yield a different renal–neurological risk profile. future studies should consider larger sample sizes, more extensive dosing protocols with drug level monitoring, additional renal biomarkers, detailed nutritional assessments and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up to clarify caffeine’s safety and efficacy in this population. back to top conclusion in summary, a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine dose given during th for moderate or severe hie lowered scr and bun but did not lessen the incidence or severity of aki. moreover, caffeine-exposed infants displayed a higher burden of mri lesions and a shift towards milder early eeg backgrounds. these retrospective findings underscore the need for prospective, dose-controlled trials—including pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up—to clarify caffeine’s renal effects and establish its neurologic safety in this population. back to top footnotes (function() { window.datalayer = window.datalayer || []; function parsecookies() { let neonataology, cleveland clinic children’s hospital, cleveland, ohio, usa\"}]}],\"abstract\":\"objective to evaluate the association of caffeine with renal and other short-term clinical outcomes in neonates with moderate or severe hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) undergoing therapeutic hypothermia (th).study design this retrospective cohort study included neonates born at ≥36 weeks gestational age with moderate or severe hie treated with th at our centre between january 2013 and december 2022. in 2019, there was a practice change to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine citrate dose for moderate/severe hie, forming two cohorts (non-caffeine vs caffeine). the primary outcome was acute kidney injury (aki), defined by modified kidney disease: improving global outcomes criteria. secondary outcomes included daily serum creatinine, blood-urea nitrogen (bun), urine output, hie-pattern lesion on brain-mri, early eeg background grade, seizures, duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay, tube-feeding at discharge and in-hospital mortality.results 85 neonates met the inclusion criteria; 38 received caffeine, and 47 did not. aki incidence was lower in the caffeine group (29% vs 47%), although not statistically significant (p=0.09). bun levels and serum creatinine levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 3–5 (p\u003c0.05). mri abnormalities consistent with hie were more frequent in the caffeine group (60% vs 36%, p=0.028), particularly in infants with moderate hie (p=0.004). eeg background profiles differed, with caffeine-exposed neonates displaying fewer severe (34% vs 65%) and more mild-to-moderate patterns. no significant differences were noted in other secondary outcomes.conclusion caffeine during th lowered serum creatinine and bun but did not significantly reduce aki and was associated with higher rates of mri lesions. prospective, dose-controlled trials with pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up are needed to clarify caffeine’s renal benefits and neurological safety in neonatal hie.\",\"datepublished\":\"2025-09-23\",\"ispartof\":{\"@type\":\"publicationissue\",\"issuenumber\":\"1\",\"pagination\":\"e003720\",\"ispartof\":{\"@type\":\"publicationvolume\",\"volumenumber\":\"9\",\"ispartof\":{\"@type\":\"periodical\",\"name\":\"bmj paediatrics open\"}}},\"url\":\"https://bmjpaedsopen.bmj.com/content/9/1/e003720\",\"description\":\"what is already known on this topic caffeine is widely used in preterm infants and observationally linked to less acute kidney injury (aki), but its renal and neurological effects during therapeutic hypothermia (th) for term hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) are unknown.\"}"]) self.__next_f.push([1,"1c:[[\"department of pediatrics, division of neonataology, cleveland clinic children’s hospital, cleveland, ohio, usa\",1],[\"department of pediatric neurology, cleveland clinic children’s hospital, cleveland, ohio, usa\",2],[\"quantitative health science, cleveland clinic, cleveland, ohio, usa\",3]]\n22:t669,nonetheless, several limitations should be considered. our retrospective design and modest sample size may have limited our ability to detect subtle effects. the lack of protein intake and nutritional status data limits our ability to interpret the lower bun levels observed in the caffeine group, as variations in dietary protein could influence bun levels. additionally, we relied on standard renal markers like scr and bun, which might not fully capture renal function nuances in neonates. the absence of long-term neurodevelopmental data prevents assessment of whether observed mri or eeg changes have lasting neurodevelopmental consequences. clinical mri reports were generated by neuroradiologists with access to the medical record, and inter-rater reliability was not assessed; likewise, eeg tracings were interpreted by several paediatric neurologists without formal assessment of inter-reader agreement, introducing additional potential for reporting bias. further, our unit adopted a single 20 mg/kg caffeine load extrapolated from preterm apnoea protocols; we did not measure serum caffeine concentrations or explore repeated dosing. consequently, we cannot determine whether the selected dose provided sufficient systemic exposure for renal benefit or whether alternative dosing regimens might yield a different renal–neurological risk profile. future studies should consider larger sample sizes, more extensive dosing protocols with drug level monitoring, additional renal biomarkers, detailed nutritional assessments and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up to clarify caffeine’s safety and efficacy in this population.24:t744,\u003chtml\u003e\u003chead\u003e\u003c/head\u003e\u003cbody\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"section fn-group\" id=\"fn-group-1\"\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli class=\"fn-ot"]) to evaluate the association of caffeine with renal and other short-term clinical outcomes in neonates with moderate or severe hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) undergoing therapeutic hypothermia (th).\"]}]}],[\"$\",\"div\",\"2\",{\"id\":\"sec-2\",\"classname\":\"subsection\",\"children\":[\"$\",\"p\",null,{\"id\":\"p-3\",\"children\":[[\"$\",\"strong\",\"0\",{\"children\":\"study design\"}],\" this retrospective cohort study included neonates born at ≥36 weeks gestational age with moderate or severe hie treated with th at our centre between january 2013 and december 2022. in 2019, there was a practice change to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine citrate dose for moderate/severe hie, forming two cohorts (non-caffeine vs caffeine). the primary outcome was acute kidney injury (aki), defined by modified kidney disease: improving global outcomes criteria. secondary outcomes included daily serum creatinine, blood-urea nitrogen (bun), urine output, hie-pattern lesion on brain-mri, early eeg background grade, seizures, duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay, tube-feeding at discharge and in-hospital mortality.\"]}]}],[\"$\",\"div\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"sec-3\",\"classname\":\"subsection\",\"children\":[\"$\",\"p\",null,{\"id\":\"p-4\",\"children\":[[\"$\",\"strong\",\"0\",{\"children\":\"results\"}],\" 85 neonates met the inclusion criteria; 38 received caffeine, and 47 did not. aki incidence was lower in the caffeine group (29% vs 47%), although not statistically significant (p=0.09). bun levels and serum creatinine levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 3–5 (p\u003c0.05). mri abnormalities consistent with hie were more frequent in the caffeine group (60% vs 36%, p=0.028), particularly in infants with moderate hie (p=0.004). eeg background profiles differed, with caffeine-exposed neonates displaying fewer severe (34% vs 65%) and more mild-to-moderate patterns. no significant differences were noted in other secondary outcomes.\"]}]}],[\"$\",\"div\",\"4\",{\"id\":\"sec-4\",\"classname\":\"subsection\",\"children\":[\"$\",\"p\",null,{\"id\":\"p-5\",\"children\":[[\"$\",\"strong\",\"0\",{\"children\":\"conclusion\"}],\" caffeine during th lowered serum creatinine and bun but did not significantly reduce aki and was associated with higher rates of mri lesions. prospective, dose-controlled trials with pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up are needed to clarify caffeine’s renal benefits and neurological safety in neonatal hie.\"]}]}]],[\"$\",\"$l1e\",null,{}]]}],false]}],[\"$\",\"$1\",\"3\",{}],[\"$\",\"$1\",\"4\",{\"children\":[[\"$\",\"div\",null,{\"classname\":\"section notes text-bmj-silver-800 \",\"id\":\"list-1\",\"children\":[\"$\",\"li\",null,{\"id\":\"list-item-1\",\"children\":[\"$\",\"p\",null,{\"id\":\"p-6\",\"children\":\"caffeine is widely used in preterm infants and observationally linked to less acute kidney injury (aki), but its renal and neurological effects during therapeutic hypothermia (th) for term hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) are
