neonataology, cleveland clinic children’s hospital, cleveland, ohio, usa\"}]}],\"abstract\":\"objective to evaluate the association of caffeine with renal and other short-term clinical outcomes in neonates with moderate or severe hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) undergoing therapeutic hypothermia (th).study design this retrospective cohort study included neonates born at ≥36 weeks gestational age with moderate or severe hie treated with th at our centre between january 2013 and december 2022. in 2019, there was a practice change to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine citrate dose for moderate/severe hie, forming two cohorts (non-caffeine vs caffeine). the primary outcome was acute kidney injury (aki), defined by modified kidney disease: improving global outcomes criteria. secondary outcomes included daily serum creatinine, blood-urea nitrogen (bun), urine output, hie-pattern lesion on brain-mri, early eeg background grade, seizures, duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay, tube-feeding at discharge and in-hospital mortality.results 85 neonates met the inclusion criteria; 38 received caffeine, and 47 did not. aki incidence was lower in the caffeine group (29% vs 47%), although not statistically significant (p=0.09). bun levels and serum creatinine levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 3–5 (p\u003c0.05). mri abnormalities consistent with hie were more frequent in the caffeine group (60% vs 36%, p=0.028), particularly in infants with moderate hie (p=0.004). eeg background profiles differed, with caffeine-exposed neonates displaying fewer severe (34% vs 65%) and more mild-to-moderate patterns. no significant differences were noted in other secondary outcomes.conclusion caffeine during th lowered serum creatinine and bun but did not significantly reduce aki and was associated with higher rates of mri lesions. prospective, dose-controlled trials with pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up are needed to clarify caffeine’s renal benefits and neurological safety in neonatal hie.\",\"datepublished\":\"2025-09-23\",\"ispartof\":{\"@type\":\"publicationissue\",\"issuenumber\":\"1\",\"pagination\":\"e003720\",\"ispartof\":{\"@type\":\"publicationvolume\",\"volumenumber\":\"9\",\"ispartof\":{\"@type\":\"periodical\",\"name\":\"bmj paediatrics open\"}}},\"url\":\"https://bmjpaedsopen.bmj.com/content/9/1/e003720\",\"description\":\"what is already known on this topic caffeine is widely used in preterm infants and observationally linked to less acute kidney injury (aki), but its renal and neurological effects during therapeutic hypothermia (th) for term hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) are unknown.\"}"]) self.__next_f.push([1,"1c:[[\"department of pediatrics, division of neonataology, cleveland clinic children’s hospital, cleveland, ohio, usa\",1],[\"department of pediatric neurology, cleveland clinic children’s hospital, cleveland, ohio, usa\",2],[\"quantitative health science, cleveland clinic, cleveland, ohio, usa\",3]]\n22:t669,nonetheless, several limitations should be considered. our retrospective design and modest sample size may have limited our ability to detect subtle effects. the lack of protein intake and nutritional status data limits our ability to interpret the lower bun levels observed in the caffeine group, as variations in dietary protein could influence bun levels. additionally, we relied on standard renal markers like scr and bun, which might not fully capture renal function nuances in neonates. the absence of long-term neurodevelopmental data prevents assessment of whether observed mri or eeg changes have lasting neurodevelopmental consequences. clinical mri reports were generated by neuroradiologists with access to the medical record, and inter-rater reliability was not assessed; likewise, eeg tracings were interpreted by several paediatric neurologists without formal assessment of inter-reader agreement, introducing additional potential for reporting bias. further, our unit adopted a single 20 mg/kg caffeine load extrapolated from preterm apnoea protocols; we did not measure serum caffeine concentrations or explore repeated dosing. consequently, we cannot determine whether the selected dose provided sufficient systemic exposure for renal benefit or whether alternative dosing regimens might yield a different renal–neurological risk profile. future studies should consider larger sample sizes, more extensive dosing protocols with drug level monitoring, additional renal biomarkers, detailed nutritional assessments and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up to clarify caffeine’s safety and efficacy in this population.24:t744,\u003chtml\u003e\u003chead\u003e\u003c/head\u003e\u003cbody\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"section fn-group\" id=\"fn-group-1\"\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli class=\"fn-ot"]) design\"}],\" this retrospective cohort study included neonates born at ≥36 weeks gestational age with moderate or severe hie treated with th at our centre between january 2013 and december 2022. in 2019, there was a practice change to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine citrate dose for moderate/severe hie, forming two cohorts (non-caffeine vs caffeine). the primary outcome was acute kidney injury (aki), defined by modified kidney disease: improving global outcomes criteria. secondary outcomes included daily serum creatinine, blood-urea nitrogen (bun), urine output, hie-pattern lesion on brain-mri, early eeg background grade, seizures, duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay, tube-feeding at discharge and in-hospital mortality.\"]}]}],[\"$\",\"div\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"sec-3\",\"classname\":\"subsection\",\"children\":[\"$\",\"p\",null,{\"id\":\"p-4\",\"children\":[[\"$\",\"strong\",\"0\",{\"children\":\"results\"}],\" 85 neonates met the inclusion criteria; 38 received caffeine, and 47 did not. aki incidence was lower in the caffeine group (29% vs 47%), although not statistically significant (p=0.09). bun levels and serum creatinine levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 3–5 (p\u003c0.05). mri abnormalities consistent with hie were more frequent in the caffeine group (60% vs 36%, p=0.028), particularly in infants with moderate hie (p=0.004). eeg background profiles differed, with caffeine-exposed neonates displaying fewer severe (34% vs 65%) and more mild-to-moderate patterns. no significant differences were noted in other secondary outcomes.\"]}]}],[\"$\",\"div\",\"4\",{\"id\":\"sec-4\",\"classname\":\"subsection\",\"children\":[\"$\",\"p\",null,{\"id\":\"p-5\",\"children\":[[\"$\",\"strong\",\"0\",{\"children\":\"conclusion\"}],\" caffeine during th lowered serum creatinine and bun but did not significantly reduce aki and was associated with higher rates of mri lesions. prospective, dose-controlled trials with pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up are needed to clarify caffeine’s renal benefits and neurological safety in neonatal hie.\"]}]}]],[\"$\",\"$l1e\",null,{}]]}],false]}],[\"$\",\"$1\",\"3\",{}],[\"$\",\"$1\",\"4\",{\"children\":[[\"$\",\"div\",null,{\"classname\":\"section notes text-bmj-silver-800 pb-[48px]\",\"data-testid\":\"article-body-section\",\"children\":[\"$\",\"section\",\"sec-8\",{\"id\":\"sec-8\",\"children\":[[[\"$\",\"h2\",\"0\",{\"classname\":\"\",\"children\":\"introduction\"}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"p-9\",\"children\":[\"hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) affects approximately 1–4 per 1000 live births in high-resource settings and remains a major cause of neonatal death and lifelong neurodisability.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-1-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-1\",\"children\":\"1\"}],\" therapeutic hypothermia (th) initiated within 6 hours of birth improves survival and neurodevelopmental outcomes, yet does not prevent multisystem sequelae.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-2-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-2\",\"children\":\"2\"}],\" acute kidney injury (aki) occurs in 20%–40% of infants with hie who underwent th and is independently associated with higher mortality, longer intensive-care stay and poorer cognitive scores at school age.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"5\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-3-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-3\",\"children\":\"3–5\"}],\" furthermore, neonates with hie who develop aki are at an increased risk of chronic kidney disease in later childhood and adolescence.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"7\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-6-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-6\",\"children\":\"6\"}],\" a single-centre cohort study demonstrated that neonatal aki in hie is associated with abnormal brain mri findings and lower bayley developmental scores.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"9\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-7-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-7\",\"children\":\"7 8\"}],\" despite the clear implication of aki on mortality and morbidity, there are currently limited therapeutic interventions available.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"2\",{\"id\":\"p-10\",\"children\":[\"several studies have investigated the potential of methylxanthines, including aminophylline and theophylline, to improve renal outcomes in neonates.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-9-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-9\",\"children\":\"9–12\"}],\" both drugs have demonstrated benefits in enhancing urine output (uop) and reducing the incidence of aki, likely through their renal vasodilatory and diuretic effects.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-13-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-13\",\"children\":\"13\"}],\" however, due to limited data on side effect profiles and pharmacokinetics of aminophylline and theophylline in neonates, they are infrequently used in clinical practice. a recent multicentre cohort of 4675 infants showed that methylxanthine exposure in neonates with hie who underwent th did not increase mortality or major morbidities, renewing interest in this drug class.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"5\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-12-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-12\",\"children\":\"12\"}]]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"p-11\",\"children\":[\"caffeine, another methylxanthine, is well tolerated in preterm infants and is widely used in neonatal intensive care units (nicus) for apnoea of prematurity.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-14-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-14\",\"children\":\"14 15\"}],\" experimental data show that adenosine-a1 receptor antagonism enhances glomerular filtration and natriuresis, while anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects may mitigate ischaemia–reperfusion injury.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-16-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-16\",\"children\":\"16\"}]]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"4\",{\"id\":\"p-12\",\"children\":[\"observational studies in very-low-birth-weight cohorts link early caffeine exposure to a lower aki risk,\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-17-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-17\",\"children\":\"17 18\"}],\" and a phase-i pharmacokinetic study in term neonates demonstrated predictable distribution during th.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-19-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-19\",\"children\":\"19\"}],\" because caffeine crosses the blood brain barrier and may raise cerebral metabolic demand, its net neurological impact in already-injured term brains remains uncertain. to date, no study has concurrently evaluated renal outcomes with brain this retrospective cohort, neonates with moderate or severe hie who received a single, protocol-driven caffeine dose during th did not show a reduction in aki (29% vs 47%), however exhibited lower scr and bun concentrations on postnatal days 3–5. taken together, these findings suggest that although caffeine may favourably influence early laboratory markers of kidney function, it did not confer a measurable clinical benefit with respect to aki in this population. conversely, infants in the caffeine group had higher rates of mri brain abnormalities consistent with hie compared with those in the non-caffeine group, particularly among infants with moderate hie. a distinct distribution of eeg background abnormalities was observed, with fewer severe but more mild/moderate patterns in the caffeine group. however, caffeine administration was not associated with significant differences in other clinical outcomes, such as seizure frequency, length of nicu stay or mortality.\"}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"2\",{\"id\":\"p-55\",\"children\":[\"caffeine’s proposed mechanisms for renal protection include vasodilatory effects, which may enhance renal blood flow, and anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties that could mitigate renal injury from oxidative stress and inflammation in hypoxic neonates.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-12-2\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-12\",\"children\":\"12 16 22\"}],\" the significantly lower bun and scr levels observed in the caffeine group suggest that caffeine may improve renal function by increasing the glomerular filtration rate.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-12-3\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-12\",\"children\":\"12 16\"}]]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"p-56\",\"children\":[\"the overall aki incidence in our cohort (37%) parallels rates reported in other contemporary therapeutic-hypothermia cohorts that used neonatal kdigo criteria—34% in sweden, 38% in turkey and 45% in a north-american registry supporting the external validity of our renal findings.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-5-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-5\",\"children\":\"5 23 24\"}],\" notably, earlier randomised trials of aminophylline/theophylline in term hie reported significant short-term falls in creatinine and oliguria,\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-9-2\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-9\",\"children\":\"9–12\"}],\" and a recent multicentre cohort of 4675 infants found no increase in mortality or major morbidities with methylxanthines use in neonates who underwent th.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"5\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-12-4\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-12\",\"children\":\"12\"}],\" our data extend this literature by showing that caffeine—the most widely used neonatal methylxanthine—improves biochemical renal indices yet does not translate into a lower aki rate when given as a single dose. multiple-dose regimens or therapeutic drug monitoring may be required to reproduce the renal benefits seen with aminophylline/theophylline.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"4\",{\"id\":\"p-57\",\"children\":[\"the higher rates of mri abnormalities observed in the caffeine group, particularly among infants with moderate hie, raise concern that adenosine-receptor blockade in an already hypoxic brain could intensify metabolic demand and potentiate tissue injury.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-25-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-25\",\"children\":\"25–27\"}],\" this interpretation must remain cautious for two reasons: clinical mri reports were not blinded to caffeine exposure, and inter-rater reliability was not assessed, leaving open the possibility of reporting bias. second, the absolute lesion burden we observed (60% in caffeine vs 36% in controls) still falls within the wide 30%–70% range documented in contemporary th cohorts,\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-2-3\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-2\",\"children\":\"2 28 29\"}],\" indicating that our rate although higher does not represent an outlier.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"5\",{\"id\":\"p-58\",\"children\":[\"the eeg findings suggest a redistribution toward milder background patterns in caffeine-exposed neonates rather than an overall worsening of electrocortical activity. such a redistribution could reflect partial normalisation, random variation or subtle baseline differences not captured in our data; it is noteworthy that similar shifts toward less discontinuous eeg have been reported after caffeine in preterm studies without accompanying reductions in seizure burden.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-30-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-30\",\"children\":\"30\"}],\" whether the observed shift represents a beneficial partial normalisation of background activity or reflects baseline differences between cohorts remains unclear, mainly because it was not accompanied by fewer seizures or mri lesions.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"6\",{\"id\":\"p-59\",\"children\":[\"despite these findings in imaging and eeg, caffeine administration was not associated with significant differences in other short-term clinical outcomes such as nicu los or mortality in either the moderate or severe hie groups. while caffeine may influence some neuroimaging markers, these changes may not translate into observable short-term clinical outcomes, possibly due to the complex nature of hie and the multifactorial interventions involved in its management.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-31-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-31\",\"children\":\"31\"}],\" the sample size also limited our ability to detect differences in outcomes. the shorter duration of mechanical ventilation in the caffeine group among infants with severe hie suggests a potential benefit of caffeine related to respiratory support. however, this difference in ventilation duration may be influenced by a small sample size and should be interpreted with caution.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"7\",{\"id\":\"p-60\",\"children\":\"the strengths of the study selection bias. additionally, this study looked at the renal and short-term neurological outcomes by assessing mri brain and eeg background abnormalities. also, this study is one of the few examining the effects of caffeine in neonates with hie treated with th, an area that remains underexplored despite the need for effective adjunct therapies in this vulnerable in this retrospective cohort, neonates with moderate or severe hie who received a single, protocol-driven caffeine dose during th did not show a reduction in aki (29% vs 47%), however exhibited lower scr and bun concentrations on postnatal days 3–5. taken together, these findings suggest that although caffeine may favourably influence early laboratory markers of kidney function, it did not confer a measurable clinical benefit with respect to aki in this population. conversely, infants in the caffeine group had higher rates of mri brain abnormalities consistent with hie compared with those in the non-caffeine group, particularly among infants with moderate hie. a distinct distribution of eeg background abnormalities was observed, with fewer severe but more mild/moderate patterns in the caffeine group. however, caffeine administration was not associated with significant differences in other clinical outcomes, such as seizure frequency, length of nicu stay or mortality. caffeine’s proposed mechanisms for renal protection include vasodilatory effects, which may enhance renal blood flow, and anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties that could mitigate renal injury from oxidative stress and inflammation in hypoxic neonates. 12 16 22 the significantly lower bun and scr levels observed in the caffeine group suggest that caffeine may improve renal function by increasing the glomerular filtration rate. 12 16 the overall aki incidence in our cohort (37%) parallels rates reported in other contemporary therapeutic-hypothermia cohorts that used neonatal kdigo criteria—34% in sweden, 38% in turkey and 45% in a north-american registry supporting the external validity of our renal findings. 5 23 24 notably, earlier randomised trials of aminophylline/theophylline in term hie reported significant short-term falls in creatinine and oliguria, 9–12 and a recent multicentre cohort of 4675 infants found no increase in mortality or major morbidities with methylxanthines use in neonates who underwent th. 12 our data extend this literature by showing that caffeine—the most widely used neonatal methylxanthine—improves biochemical renal indices yet does not translate into a lower aki rate when given as a single dose. multiple-dose regimens or therapeutic drug monitoring may be required to reproduce the renal benefits seen with aminophylline/theophylline. the higher rates of mri abnormalities observed in the caffeine group, particularly among infants with moderate hie, raise concern that adenosine-receptor blockade in an already hypoxic brain could intensify metabolic demand and potentiate tissue injury. 25–27 this interpretation must remain cautious for two reasons: clinical mri reports were not blinded to caffeine exposure, and inter-rater reliability was not assessed, leaving open the possibility of reporting bias. second, the absolute lesion burden we observed (60% in caffeine vs 36% in controls) still falls within the wide 30%–70% range documented in contemporary th cohorts, 2 28 29 indicating that our rate although higher does not represent an outlier. the eeg findings suggest a redistribution toward milder background patterns in caffeine-exposed neonates rather than an overall worsening of electrocortical activity. such a redistribution could reflect partial normalisation, random variation or subtle baseline differences not captured in our data; it is noteworthy that similar shifts toward less discontinuous eeg have been reported after caffeine in preterm studies without accompanying reductions in seizure burden. 30 whether the observed shift represents a beneficial partial normalisation of background activity or reflects baseline differences between cohorts remains unclear, mainly because it was not accompanied by fewer seizures or mri lesions. despite these findings in imaging and eeg, caffeine administration was not associated with significant differences in other short-term clinical outcomes such as nicu los or mortality in either the moderate or severe hie groups. while caffeine may influence some neuroimaging markers, these changes may not translate into observable short-term clinical outcomes, possibly due to the complex nature of hie and the multifactorial interventions involved in its management. 31 the sample size also limited our ability to detect differences in outcomes. the shorter duration of mechanical ventilation in the caffeine group among infants with severe hie suggests a potential benefit of caffeine related to respiratory support. however, this difference in ventilation duration may be influenced by a small sample size and should be interpreted with caution. the strengths of the study include a well-defined cohort of neonates treated with standardised th protocols and a consistent caffeine administration to all eligible infants born between 2019 and 2022, minimising potential selection bias. additionally, this study looked at the renal and short-term neurological outcomes by assessing mri brain and eeg background abnormalities. also, this study is one of the few examining the effects of caffeine in neonates with hie treated with th, an area that remains underexplored despite the need for effective adjunct therapies in this vulnerable population. nonetheless, several limitations should be considered. our retrospective design and modest sample size may have limited our ability to detect subtle effects. the lack of protein intake and nutritional status data limits our ability to interpret the lower bun levels observed in the caffeine group, as variations in dietary protein could influence bun levels. additionally, we relied on standard renal markers like scr and bun, which might not fully capture renal function nuances in neonates. the absence of long-term neurodevelopmental data prevents assessment of whether observed mri or eeg changes have lasting neurodevelopmental consequences. clinical mri reports were generated by neuroradiologists with access to the medical record, and inter-rater reliability was not assessed; likewise, eeg tracings were interpreted by several paediatric neurologists without formal assessment of inter-reader agreement, introducing additional potential for reporting bias. further, our unit adopted a single 20 mg/kg caffeine load extrapolated from preterm apnoea protocols; we did not measure serum caffeine concentrations or explore repeated dosing. consequently, we cannot determine whether the selected dose provided sufficient systemic exposure for renal benefit or whether alternative dosing regimens might yield a different renal–neurological risk profile. future studies should consider larger sample sizes, more extensive dosing protocols with drug level monitoring, additional renal biomarkers, detailed nutritional assessments and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up to clarify caffeine’s safety and efficacy in this population. back to top conclusion in summary, a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine dose given during th for moderate or severe hie lowered scr and bun but did not lessen the incidence or severity of aki. moreover, caffeine-exposed infants displayed a higher burden of mri lesions and a shift towards milder early eeg backgrounds. these retrospective findings underscore the need for prospective, dose-controlled trials—including pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up—to clarify caffeine’s renal effects and establish its neurologic safety in this population. back to top footnotes (function() { window.datalayer = self.__next_f.push([1,"8:null\ne:t7cf,objective to evaluate the association of caffeine with renal and other short-term clinical outcomes in neonates with moderate or severe hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) undergoing therapeutic hypothermia (th).study design this retrospective cohort study included neonates born at ≥36 weeks gestational age with moderate or severe hie treated with th at our centre between january 2013 and december 2022. in 2019, there was a practice change to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine citrate dose for moderate/severe hie, forming two cohorts (non-caffeine vs caffeine). the primary outcome was acute kidney injury (aki), defined by modified kidney disease: improving global outcomes criteria. secondary outcomes included daily serum creatinine, blood-urea nitrogen (bun), urine output, hie-pattern lesion on brain-mri, early eeg background grade, seizures, duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay, tube-feeding at discharge and in-hospital mortality.results 85 neonates met the inclusion criteria; 38 received caffeine, and 47 did not. aki incidence was lower in the caffeine group (29% vs 47%), although not statistically significant (p=0.09). bun levels and serum creatinine levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 3–5 (p\u003c0.05). mri abnormalities consistent with hie were more frequent in the caffeine group (60% vs 36%, p=0.028), particularly in infants with moderate hie (p=0.004). eeg background profiles differed, with caffeine-exposed neonates displaying fewer severe (34% vs 65%) and more mild-to-moderate patterns. no significant differences were noted in other secondary outcomes.conclusion caffeine during th lowered serum creatinine and bun but did not significantly reduce aki and was associated with higher rates of mri lesions. prospective, dose-controlled trials with pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up are needed to clarify caffeine’s renal benefits and neurological safety in neonatal hie.f:t7cf,objective to evaluate the as"]) self.__next_f.push([1,"sociation of caffeine with renal and other short-term clinical outcomes neonates with moderate or severe hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) undergoing therapeutic hypothermia (th).study design this retrospective cohort study included neonates born at ≥36 weeks gestational age with moderate or severe hie treated with th at our centre between january 2013 and december 2022. in 2019, there was a practice change to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine citrate dose for moderate/severe hie, forming two cohorts (non-caffeine vs caffeine). the primary outcome was acute kidney injury (aki), defined by modified kidney disease: improving global outcomes criteria. secondary outcomes included daily serum creatinine, blood-urea nitrogen (bun), urine output, hie-pattern lesion on brain-mri, early eeg background grade, seizures, duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay, tube-feeding at discharge and in-hospital mortality.results 85 neonates met the inclusion criteria; 38 received caffeine, and 47 did not. aki incidence was lower in the caffeine group (29% vs 47%), although not statistically significant (p=0.09). bun levels and serum creatinine levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 3–5 (p\u003c0.05). mri abnormalities consistent with hie were more frequent in the caffeine group (60% vs 36%, p=0.028), particularly in infants with moderate hie (p=0.004). eeg background profiles differed, with caffeine-exposed neonates displaying fewer severe (34% vs 65%) and more mild-to-moderate patterns. no significant differences were noted in other secondary outcomes.conclusion caffeine during th lowered serum creatinine and bun but did not significantly reduce aki and was associated with higher rates of mri lesions. prospective, dose-controlled trials with pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up are needed to clarify caffeine’s renal benefits and neurological safety in neonatal hie.\",\"datepublished\":\"2025-09-23\",\"ispartof\":{\"@type\":\"publicationissue\",\"issuenumber\":\"1\",\"pagination\":\"e003720\",\"ispartof\":{\"@type\":\"publicationvolume\",\"volumenumber\":\"9\",\"ispartof\":{\"@type\":\"periodical\",\"name\":\"bmj paediatrics open\"}}},\"url\":\"https://bmjpaedsopen.bmj.com/content/9/1/e003720\",\"description\":\"what is already known on this topic caffeine is widely used in preterm infants and observationally linked to less acute kidney injury (aki), but its renal and neurological effects during therapeutic hypothermia (th) for term hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (hie) are unknown.\"}"]) self.__next_f.push([1,"1c:[[\"department of pediatrics, division of neonataology, cleveland clinic children’s hospital, cleveland, ohio, usa\",1],[\"department of pediatric neurology, cleveland clinic children’s hospital, cleveland, ohio, usa\",2],[\"quantitative health science, cleveland clinic, cleveland, ohio, usa\",3]]\n22:t669,nonetheless, several limitations should be considered. our retrospective design and modest sample size may have limited our ability to detect subtle effects. the lack of protein intake and nutritional status data limits our ability to interpret the lower bun levels observed in the caffeine group, as variations in dietary protein could influence bun levels. additionally, we relied on standard renal markers like scr and bun, which might not fully capture renal function nuances in neonates. the absence of long-term neurodevelopmental data prevents assessment of whether observed mri or eeg changes have lasting neurodevelopmental consequences. clinical mri reports were generated by neuroradiologists with access to the medical record, and inter-rater reliability was not assessed; likewise, eeg tracings were interpreted by several paediatric neurologists without formal assessment of inter-reader agreement, introducing additional potential for reporting bias. further, our unit adopted a single 20 mg/kg caffeine load extrapolated from preterm apnoea protocols; we did not measure serum caffeine concentrations or explore repeated dosing. consequently, we cannot determine whether the selected dose provided sufficient systemic exposure for renal benefit or whether alternative dosing regimens might yield a different renal–neurological risk profile. future studies should consider larger sample sizes, more extensive dosing protocols with drug level monitoring, additional renal biomarkers, detailed nutritional assessments and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up to clarify caffeine’s safety and efficacy in this design\"}],\" this retrospective cohort study included neonates born at ≥36 weeks gestational age with moderate or severe hie treated with th at our centre between january 2013 and december 2022. in 2019, there was a practice change to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg caffeine citrate dose for moderate/severe hie, forming two cohorts (non-caffeine vs caffeine). the primary outcome was acute kidney injury (aki), defined by modified kidney disease: improving global outcomes criteria. secondary outcomes included daily serum creatinine, blood-urea nitrogen (bun), urine output, hie-pattern lesion on brain-mri, early eeg background grade, seizures, duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay, tube-feeding at discharge and in-hospital 85 neonates met the inclusion criteria; 38 received caffeine, and 47 did not. aki incidence was lower in the caffeine group (29% vs 47%), although not statistically significant (p=0.09). bun levels and serum creatinine levels were significantly lower in the caffeine group on days 3–5 (p\u003c0.05). mri abnormalities consistent with hie were more frequent in the caffeine group (60% vs 36%, p=0.028), particularly in infants with moderate hie (p=0.004). eeg background profiles differed, with caffeine-exposed neonates displaying fewer severe (34% vs 65%) and more mild-to-moderate patterns. no significant differences were noted in other secondary outcomes.\"]}]}],[\"$\",\"div\",\"4\",{\"id\":\"sec-4\",\"classname\":\"subsection\",\"children\":[\"$\",\"p\",null,{\"id\":\"p-5\",\"children\":[[\"$\",\"strong\",\"0\",{\"children\":\"conclusion\"}],\" caffeine during th lowered serum creatinine and bun but did not significantly reduce aki and was associated with higher rates of mri lesions. prospective, dose-controlled trials with pharmacokinetic monitoring and long-term neurodevelopmental follow-up are needed to clarify caffeine’s renal benefits and neurological safety in neonatal encephalopathy (hie) affects approximately 1–4 per 1000 live births in high-resource settings and remains a major cause of neonatal death and lifelong neurodisability.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-1-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-1\",\"children\":\"1\"}],\" therapeutic hypothermia (th) initiated within 6 hours of birth improves survival and neurodevelopmental outcomes, yet does not prevent multisystem sequelae.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-2-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-2\",\"children\":\"2\"}],\" acute kidney injury (aki) occurs in 20%–40% of infants with hie who underwent th and is independently associated with higher mortality, longer intensive-care stay and poorer cognitive scores at school age.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"5\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-3-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-3\",\"children\":\"3–5\"}],\" furthermore, neonates with hie who develop aki are at an increased risk of chronic kidney disease in later childhood and adolescence.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"7\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-6-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-6\",\"children\":\"6\"}],\" a single-centre cohort study demonstrated that neonatal aki in hie is associated with abnormal brain mri findings and lower bayley developmental scores.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"9\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-7-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-7\",\"children\":\"7 8\"}],\" despite the clear implication of aki on mortality and morbidity, there are currently limited therapeutic interventions available.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"2\",{\"id\":\"p-10\",\"children\":[\"several studies have investigated the potential of methylxanthines, including aminophylline and theophylline, to improve renal outcomes in neonates.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-9-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-9\",\"children\":\"9–12\"}],\" both drugs have demonstrated benefits in enhancing urine output (uop) and reducing the incidence of aki, likely through their renal vasodilatory and diuretic effects.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-13-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-13\",\"children\":\"13\"}],\" however, due to limited data on side effect profiles and pharmacokinetics of aminophylline and theophylline in neonates, they are infrequently used in clinical practice. a recent multicentre cohort of 4675 infants showed that methylxanthine exposure in neonates with hie who underwent th did not increase mortality or major morbidities, renewing interest in this drug class.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"5\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-12-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-12\",\"children\":\"12\"}]]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"p-11\",\"children\":[\"caffeine, another methylxanthine, is well tolerated in preterm infants and is widely used in neonatal intensive care units (nicus) for apnoea of prematurity.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-14-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-14\",\"children\":\"14 15\"}],\" experimental data show that adenosine-a1 receptor antagonism enhances glomerular filtration and natriuresis, while anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects may mitigate ischaemia–reperfusion injury.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-16-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-16\",\"children\":\"16\"}]]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"4\",{\"id\":\"p-12\",\"children\":[\"observational studies in very-low-birth-weight cohorts link early caffeine exposure to a lower aki risk,\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-17-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-17\",\"children\":\"17 18\"}],\" and a phase-i pharmacokinetic study in term neonates demonstrated predictable distribution during th.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-19-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-19\",\"children\":\"19\"}],\" because caffeine crosses the blood brain barrier and may raise cerebral metabolic demand, its net neurological impact in already-injured term brains remains uncertain. to date, no study has concurrently evaluated renal outcomes with brain mri and continuous eeg in this context.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"5\",{\"id\":\"p-13\",\"children\":[\"prompted by the kidney disease: improving global outcomes (kdigo) aki guideline’s suggestion to consider a single prophylactic methylxanthine dose for term infants with perinatal asphyxia and by the extensive safety record of caffeine in neonatal care, our units adopted a protocol in 2019 to administer a single intravenous 20 mg/kg dose of caffeine citrate within 24 hours of birth to every infant with moderate or severe hie undergoing th.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-20-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-20\",\"children\":\"20\"}],\" this retrospective cohort study compares infants treated before and after this retrospective cohort, neonates with moderate or severe hie who received a single, protocol-driven caffeine dose during th did not show a reduction in aki (29% vs 47%), however exhibited lower scr and bun concentrations on postnatal days 3–5. taken together, these findings suggest that although caffeine may favourably influence early laboratory markers of kidney function, it did not confer a measurable clinical benefit with respect to aki in this population. conversely, infants in the caffeine group had higher rates of mri brain abnormalities consistent with hie compared with those in the non-caffeine group, particularly among infants with moderate hie. a distinct distribution of eeg background abnormalities was observed, with fewer severe but more mild/moderate patterns in the caffeine group. however, caffeine administration was not associated with significant differences in other clinical outcomes, such as seizure frequency, length of nicu stay or mortality.\"}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"2\",{\"id\":\"p-55\",\"children\":[\"caffeine’s proposed mechanisms for renal protection include vasodilatory effects, which may enhance renal blood flow, and anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties that could mitigate renal injury from oxidative stress and inflammation in hypoxic neonates.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-12-2\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-12\",\"children\":\"12 16 22\"}],\" the significantly lower bun and scr levels observed in the caffeine group suggest that caffeine may improve renal function by increasing the glomerular filtration rate.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-12-3\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-12\",\"children\":\"12 16\"}]]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"p-56\",\"children\":[\"the overall aki incidence in our cohort (37%) parallels rates reported in other contemporary therapeutic-hypothermia cohorts that used neonatal kdigo criteria—34% in sweden, 38% in turkey and 45% in a north-american registry supporting the external validity of our renal findings.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-5-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-5\",\"children\":\"5 23 24\"}],\" notably, earlier randomised trials of aminophylline/theophylline in term hie reported significant short-term falls in creatinine and oliguria,\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-9-2\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-9\",\"children\":\"9–12\"}],\" and a recent multicentre cohort of 4675 infants found no increase in mortality or major morbidities with methylxanthines use in neonates who underwent th.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"5\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-12-4\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-12\",\"children\":\"12\"}],\" our data extend this literature by showing that caffeine—the most widely used neonatal methylxanthine—improves biochemical renal indices yet does not translate into a lower aki rate when given as a single dose. multiple-dose regimens or therapeutic drug monitoring may be required to reproduce the renal benefits seen with aminophylline/theophylline.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"4\",{\"id\":\"p-57\",\"children\":[\"the higher rates of mri abnormalities observed in the caffeine group, particularly among infants with moderate hie, raise concern that adenosine-receptor blockade in an already hypoxic brain could intensify metabolic demand and potentiate tissue injury.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-25-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-25\",\"children\":\"25–27\"}],\" this interpretation must remain cautious for two reasons: clinical mri reports were not blinded to caffeine exposure, and inter-rater reliability was not assessed, leaving open the possibility of reporting bias. second, the absolute lesion burden we observed (60% in caffeine vs 36% in controls) still falls within the wide 30%–70% range documented in contemporary th cohorts,\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"3\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-2-3\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-2\",\"children\":\"2 28 29\"}],\" indicating that our rate although higher does not represent an outlier.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"5\",{\"id\":\"p-58\",\"children\":[\"the eeg findings suggest a redistribution toward milder background patterns in caffeine-exposed neonates rather than an overall worsening of electrocortical activity. such a redistribution could reflect partial normalisation, random variation or subtle baseline differences not captured in our data; it is noteworthy that similar shifts toward less discontinuous eeg have been reported after caffeine in preterm studies without accompanying reductions in seizure burden.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-30-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-30\",\"children\":\"30\"}],\" whether the observed shift represents a beneficial partial normalisation of background activity or reflects baseline differences between cohorts remains unclear, mainly because it was not accompanied by fewer seizures or mri lesions.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"6\",{\"id\":\"p-59\",\"children\":[\"despite these findings in imaging and eeg, caffeine administration was not associated with significant differences in other short-term clinical outcomes such as nicu los or mortality in either the moderate or severe hie groups. while caffeine may influence some neuroimaging markers, these changes may not translate into observable short-term clinical outcomes, possibly due to the complex nature of hie and the multifactorial interventions involved in its management.\",[\"$\",\"a\",\"1\",{\"id\":\"xref-ref-31-1\",\"classname\":\"xref-bibr\",\"href\":\"#ref-31\",\"children\":\"31\"}],\" the sample size also limited our ability to detect differences in difference in ventilation duration may be influenced by a small sample size and should be interpreted with caution.\"]}],[\"$\",\"p\",\"7\",{\"id\":\"p-60\",\"children\":\"the strengths of the study
